question: According to IFRS standards, which of the following metrics is required to be disclosed by both Electric Utilities & Power Generators and Gas Utilities & Distributors?
optionA: Greenhouse gas emissions associated with power deliveries
optionB: Number of incidents of non-compliance with physical and/or cybersecurity standards
optionC: Percentage of electric load served by smart grid technology
optionD: Customer gas savings from efficiency measures by market
optionE: Number of: (1) residential, (2) commercial, and (3) industrial customers served
answer: E. Number of: (1) residential, (2) commercial, and (3) industrial customers served
explanation: Both Electric Utilities & Power Generators (IF-EU-000.A) and Gas Utilities & Distributors (IF-GU-000.A) are required to disclose the number of residential, commercial, and industrial customers served as an activity metric according to IFRS standards.
references: IFRS S2 Climate-related Disclosures Appendix B Industry-based disclosure requirements: Electric Utilities & Power Generators
IFRS S2 Climate-related Disclosures Appendix B Industry-based disclosure requirements: Gas Utilities & Distributors
pairing_explanation: Both industries are pivotal in the energy sector and their sustainability efforts are crucial for transitioning to low-carbon energy sources. Comparing these can provide insights into their environmental impacts, energy efficiency, and regulatory compliance.

question: When disclosing information about incidents related to infrastructure safety, which of the following is a key difference between Electric Utilities & Power Generators and Gas Utilities & Distributors reporting requirements?
optionA: Electric utilities must report on cybersecurity incidents, while gas utilities do not
optionB: Gas utilities must report on pipeline incidents, while electric utilities do not have a comparable requirement
optionC: Electric utilities must report on nuclear safety, while gas utilities do not have any safety reporting requirements
optionD: Gas utilities must report on distribution pipeline materials, while electric utilities do not have any infrastructure material reporting requirements
optionE: Electric utilities must report on transmission line length, while gas utilities do not have any infrastructure length reporting requirements
answer: B. Gas utilities must report on pipeline incidents, while electric utilities do not have a comparable requirement
explanation: Gas Utilities & Distributors are required to disclose the number of reportable pipeline incidents (IF-GU-540a.1), while Electric Utilities & Power Generators do not have a directly comparable requirement for their infrastructure. This reflects the different safety concerns and regulatory focus between the two industries.

IFRS S2 Climate-related Disclosures Appendix B Industry-based disclosure requirements: Gas Utilities & Distributors

question: When calculating customer energy savings for sustainability reporting, what is a key difference between Electric Utilities & Power Generators and Gas Utilities & Distributors?
optionA: Electric utilities report savings in kilowatt-hours, while gas utilities report in British thermal units
optionB: Electric utilities include industrial customers, while gas utilities exclude them
optionC: Gas utilities report savings by market, while electric utilities report aggregate savings
optionD: Electric utilities use net savings, while gas utilities use gross savings
optionE: Gas utilities include efficiency credits purchased, while electric utilities exclude them
answer: A. Electric utilities report savings in kilowatt-hours, while gas utilities report in British thermal units
explanation: Electric Utilities & Power Generators report customer electricity savings in megawatt hours (MWh) (IF-EU-420a.3), while Gas Utilities & Distributors report customer gas savings in million British thermal units (MMBtu) (IF-GU-420a.2). This difference reflects the distinct units of measurement typically used for electricity and natural gas consumption.
references: IFRS S2 Climate-related Disclosures Appendix B Industry-based disclosure requirements: Electric Utilities & Power Generators

question: In the context of infrastructure integrity reporting, which of the following metrics is unique to Gas Utilities & Distributors and not required for Electric Utilities & Power Generators?
optionB: Percentage of gas transmission pipelines inspected
optionC: Number of incidents of non-compliance with physical and/or cybersecurity standards
optionD: Description of efforts to manage nuclear safety
optionE: Total electricity generated by major energy source
answer: B. Percentage of gas transmission pipelines inspected
explanation: The percentage of gas transmission pipelines inspected (IF-GU-540a.3) is a metric specific to Gas Utilities & Distributors. This metric is crucial for assessing the integrity and safety of gas delivery infrastructure, which is not applicable to Electric Utilities & Power Generators in the same way.

question: How do the greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions reporting requirements differ between Electric Utilities & Power Generators and Gas Utilities & Distributors?
optionA: Electric utilities must report Scope 1, 2, and 3 emissions, while gas utilities only report Scope 1
optionB: Gas utilities must report fugitive emissions, while electric utilities are exempt from this requirement
optionC: Electric utilities must report emissions associated with power deliveries, while gas utilities have no specific GHG reporting requirements
optionD: Gas utilities must report emissions from pipeline leaks, while electric utilities only report emissions from power generation
optionE: Electric and gas utilities have identical GHG reporting requirements
answer: C. Electric utilities must report emissions associated with power deliveries, while gas utilities have no specific GHG reporting requirements
explanation: Electric Utilities & Power Generators are required to report greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions associated with power deliveries (IF-EU-110a.2). In contrast, the IFRS standards for Gas Utilities & Distributors do not include a specific metric for reporting GHG emissions, although they do address efforts to manage emissions in the context of infrastructure integrity (IF-GU-540a.4).

question: In terms of infrastructure resilience and reliability reporting, what is a key difference between Electric Utilities & Power Generators and Gas Utilities & Distributors?
optionA: Electric utilities report on grid resilience, while gas utilities report on pipeline integrity
optionB: Gas utilities report on cyber attacks, while electric utilities report on physical attacks
optionC: Electric utilities report on weather-related disruptions, while gas utilities do not have to report on any disruptions
optionD: Gas utilities report on storage facility safety, while electric utilities report on transmission line safety
optionE: Electric and gas utilities have identical infrastructure resilience reporting requirements
answer: A. Electric utilities report on grid resilience, while gas utilities report on pipeline integrity
explanation: Electric Utilities & Power Generators are required to report on grid resilience, including metrics such as SAIDI, SAIFI, and CAIDI (IF-EU-550a.2). In contrast, Gas Utilities & Distributors report on pipeline integrity, including metrics related to pipeline incidents, pipeline materials, and inspection rates (IF-GU-540a.1, IF-GU-540a.2, IF-GU-540a.3). This difference reflects the distinct infrastructure challenges and safety concerns in each industry.

IFRS S2 Climate-related Disclosures Appendix B Industry-based disclosure requirements: Gas Utilities & Distributors
